name: The Ricky Gervais Guide to: The World Cup

transcript.content: As Bill Shankley once said, some people think football is a matter of life and death. I assure you it's much more serious than that. The World cup is the most watched sporting event in the world, with 32 teams battling it out for the most coveted prize in football. For the first time in history, an African nation will host the tournament this year. Seen as controversial by some and by others as an example of soccer's ability to be progressive and inspiring, how will England fare? Which teams are the frontrunners and who are the rank outsiders? To discuss the beautiful game, I'm joined by Stephen Merchant, a award winning writer and graduate of the University of Warwick.
Hello.
And Karl Pilkington, a man with a head like a fucking football. An orange one. Oh, I am finished. CUNT!
All right.
What are you doing?
Try to calm your gums down.
We don't do it with water.
What do you do it with?
You're trying to calm your gums down, what's up with em?
You do it with meditation and hard drugs.
What's the problem with your gums?
When I'm stressed out, my teeth know.
What? What do you mean?
Say that again.
When I'm sort of stressed out, me gums and me teeth know before I do. It's like a weakness.
So what's up? You got a toothache, then?
Mmmm.
I thought you went to the dentist!
I did the other week.
Well, what's wrong with your teeth, then? It's just because you're stressed?
I don't know.
Why are you stressed? What have you got to be stressed about?
I don't know. That's what's weird with stress in it.
No!
Your body can be stressed without you realizing. That's what kills people.
Stressed? No, nononono, you're stressed because you feel stressed and then your body gets weak because you're.
No, because I'm pretty good. I never feel stressed. That's part of my problem. I am stressed, but I don't know about it.
That doesn't make any sense at all.
It's number one killer!
You never get stressed!
If you don't feel stressed, how are you stressed?
But you must be stressed if your teeth are telling you you're stressed.
It's like saying 'I didn't feel like I had a pain, but apparently I did.'
Listen.
Go on.
I was in Israel recently. I had a bag put over my head, chucked in the back of the van. Now, the thing is, I kind of thought.. well..
It wasn't a blind date, by the way, and he wasn't being arrested or kidnapped. It was a training thing, wasn't it, for kidnapping situations?
I didn't know.
You didn't know they were going to do it?
No, they don't tell me anything do they?
That's good.
So what happened then?

So the thing is, that happened, I had a panic on a little bit. Afterwards, they took the bag off. I realized everything was all right. I was calm, but my body was shaking. And that's what I'm saying to ya.
That doesn't make any sense.
My body, as far as my body was concerned, it had just been kidnapped.
Right.
But I knew I hadn't. Anyway, football.
You know the bag they put over your head? Was it like a tennis racket cover? What shape was it?
You sure they just didn't go and thought, oh, I thought I'd just bought the world's biggest orange.
Come on, let's do this.
Right.
Soccer.
Yeah, the World cup. We'd jump on the bandwagon with every other pucker who's doing a World cup podcast, even though we've got nothing to say about it.
Whoa.
What?
I got a few things.
Yeah, but it's going to be so disappointing. We're going to get excited, we're going to sit down. In fact, if you're listening to this now, England are probably out of the fucking World Cup.
Steve laughs
I disagree with you. I'm right behind the lads.
Yeah. Right. Okay.

But do you remember, because I've watched the World Cup a few times with Ricky in different projects we've been doing in the past, we've been in different situations. Do you remember when I think the last time we qualified, we were doing a project and we watched it together in hotel room?
We were watching Extras, right?
Making Extras. Watching football.

Making Extras, yeah. And we watched it. We said, oh, I'll go into my room. I went to Steve's room, but of course, in the hotel room, it was just like a big bed. So we sat on the bed together and we thought that was a bit intense, so I put a line of pillows down.
But I don't understand what... He put a line of pillows between us. Now he knows I'm not going to jump on him.
No, I know!
He's not going to jump on me.
No.

But he's still terrified that some kind of paparazzi is going to sort of parascend down the building and peer in and take a photo of us and that's before we've got time to explain that we're just watching the football. It's already printed, going, well this is clearly evidence of they're gay. There's no way that they could possibly be sat on a bed just as friends.
No, but hold on, though. Why were we naked? Why didn't we just pop some trousers on?
But I seem to remember that even though it was my room. You forced me to sit in the chair. It was one of those really uncomfortable box chairs.
I said, it's weird. I can't get excited. We're having a beer, okay? So now we're drinking. Now we're drinking in bed.
We weren't in bed!
No no no. We had our clothes on. We're on the bed watching football. But I couldn't go, come on, England. With a little man sitting next to me in the bed.
Not a little man at all.
No, big man. And so I just thought, let's pop the pillows down. That wasn't enough. I said, Steve, I can't do this. I can't watch football with a man on a bed. I said, so go in the chair.
And he sat in this chair!
So I sat in the chair which is, if you're a man of my size, those tiny little crappy hotel box chairs are no good. It's 90 bloody minutes plus the intermission. It was my room. I was furious.

I felt like I was like an old rich man just waiting to die. And my little man servant used to come and sit and watch football with me in the last days of my time. I'm in bed going, oh it's gone again. He goes, all right, I'll put it up later. Look, Rooney's taking a penalty. No, it's gone. It's all out. I go, oh, dear. Yeah, let me clean it up. We can put this on pause.
It's sky plus.
Let's open a window.
Yeah.

But the thing is, often I think football fans are very homo erotic. They're hugging each other, jumping on each other, swapping shirts and stuff. So there's nothing wrong with being intimate watching a football game.

Yeah, but I don't think gay people do that. Gay people don't run around hugging each other and swapping shirts, do they? They get stuck in. Karl, would you sit on a bed right with Stephen in a hotel room, right. Watching football? Okay. You're pouring each other wine and beer and champagne.
Ricky does romantic music
Well, no, there wasn't that music playing. There was the roar of the crowd and John Motson doing commentary. It's not a sexy sound at all.
Ricky bursts
What do you think, Karl?
Erm...
Someone said, oh, come to my room, we're watching football. You got there and he went...
Ricky does romantic music again
Well who was on the
Steve and Karl talk over each other
Who was on the bed first?
That's not what happened!
Who was on the bed first?
Well, he probably got up to answer the door. So I don't know. I came in, I thought, well, there's only a bed here. We sat down, we thought, yeah...
No, but it wasn't.
There was a chair there.
Well, yeah, but you know full well that if you're in a room with Ricky. He's the one who's going to leap straight on the bed and demand that you.
I'd just take the chair.
Why would you be concerned with lying on a bed next to me?
Yeah, what's up with that?
Just a bit weird, isn't it?
Why?
Why is it weird? I don't understand this.
Because..
I've changed my tune.
A bit weird lying on a bed with a mate, just watching football.
Yeah. You don't like when you go around a house, do you?
Yeah, but that's because you have a sofa and things! We didn't have that in the room.
Yeah, but when you visit someone in hospital, you don't say, move over. You don't pop yourself down next to them. You sit on the chair.
No, because you're not there in a relaxed situation for 90 minutes, enjoying a game of sport. It's just a more formal environment. Because you're quite a sport fan, aren't you, Karl?
Yeah, but not in. I don't like getting into things too much because it can only be disappointing.
Well that's true. I've never seen him get into anything, to be quite honest.

No, I am a football fan, but I've got it now to a point where if they lose, it only bothers me for about half an hour and then I move on. Because the thing is, I'm not in control of it. There's nothing I can do to alter that team. If I could go in and say, listen, you're lazy. You get your finger out. You move up front a bit. It's different, but it's totally. It's like getting annoyed with nature. There's nothing you can do, so let it happen. Watch it if you want, but don't get annoyed about it because it's totally out of your hands.
Interesting that Karl's team tactics also sounds like he could be directing a gay porn.
Ricky bursts
You get your finger out, you get up front, you're lazy.

That's amazing. What do you think of these people, though? I love it that everyone's an expert, everyone's a pundit. You see these fat people in pubs going, well, he's lost a few yards up front. Yeah. You fucking score a goal, then fatty.
Wearing a football top.
Yeah.
I hate that.
Exactly. Yeah.
They shouldn't make them for them. Shouldn't make them in that size. It should be one size only. If you're fit enough to play football, you can wear one. If you're a fatty, you're not.
Ricky laughs
Because it looks ridiculous anyway.
But what's that?! What are you talking about?!
So a big fat slob with his belly out in an England shirt. Going, I could score from there. Go on, then, let's have a go.

Hey, listen, calm down. Don't be slagging off the fans, because that's what it's all about. Football's all about the supporters isn't it. You know let's not forget these people are paid millions to entertain us. If we want to drink till we're fat and eat pork pies and then put on an England shirt, we'll do it. That is the British way. That is the English way. That is what we won a war for.
What difference does it make if we win or lose? That's what I always look at, the end result.
How can you say you like football and then give us that argument? The only reason to watch football is the excitement of the challenge.
Yeah, it's entertainment.
Well and a bit of skill. It's nice to see a bit of skill and go "That was clever".
Yeah only because it's entertaining.
Yeah, but what I'm saying is, enjoy the game for what it is and then forget about it. If fat Bob in the pub, he's got his football top on.
Just.
He gets all annoyed when England lose, what difference it make? What difference does it make if they lose there or lose in the final? What's the point?
Well, I'll tell you what difference it makes. I knew a fat Bob, okay? That wasn't his name, but I'm changing the name to protect the innocent and him. And he's not innocent, right?
Was it fat Dave?

It was a big fat bloke, right? And he worked on one of the crews that used to bring in equipment where I used to work at the students union, okay? And he was massive, right? And I think it was 1990 or 1992, the euro, when England got knocked out and he went mental and he was so angry, he went out and he wanted retribution, okay? Luckily there were no German people around, but the closest he could find was a sausage van.
Steve laughs
Some poor bloke who delivered sausages and he turned it over. He got the van and he turned it over because it was selling sausages. So he thought, that's German enough.
No, if he's fat, it's probably just annoyed that it wasn't open.
Ricky and Steve laugh together
I'm very excited because Peter Crouch is in the tournament. Now Peter Crouch...
You identify with him don't you?
I love Crouchy. He's exactly the same height as me, six foot seven.
He's sort of lanky and awkward looking.
Right.

But brilliant. I mean, still a very, you know, let's not forget that he is playing in the national squad. He is a striker. He's got an excellent track record of scoring for England. Admittedly, maybe not in the super top important games, but nevertheless tremendous track record.
He's like your role model. He's like your pin up isn't he?

He wrote an autobiography, which I was going to call my autobiography, Tall Stories. Crouchy got there first, but good luck to him. I'll give it to him. I'm happy for him to do that. I once got. Someone had come up to me in a club once and said, are you Peter Crouch? I said, yeah.
Ricky sniggers
I thought, she thinks I'm Crouchy. What's the problem? Let's see how far we can get with this before the truth will out. But I was disappointed...
"I didn't know you wore glasses?"
No, exactly. I'm sort of off duty, you know what I mean?
Yeah.
I don't wear them on the field.
Do you think he'd have had a different career if he'd have worn glasses from the age of five, like you?
This is one of the reasons I've not been a great footballer. Have you ever seen me doing any form of athletics or sport?
No.
Because I like to think I look quite elegant. I feel like I'm actually in control of it. But when I look back, if someone's videoed it, I look like one of those giant costumes in. It's a knockout.
Ricky laughs
You know where the arms are flapping.
The false head.
And they just fall over.
No real expression on their head. Yeah.

But one of the things I was disappointed at, I was looking at because obviously around this time of year, there's lots of advertising because of the footballers are all getting endorsements and I was looking to see what each one are doing. And Wayne Rooney, he's got endorsement deals with Nike, with Nokia, with Coca Cola. Lampard, Pepsi and Adidas. Peter Crouch, you know what he's advertising?
Go on.
Pringles. It's not the coolest one, is it? Pringles? I mean, even the name Pringles, really.
I know. It's sort of like an insult, isn't.
It is.
Who's that Pringle? Eh hold on..
Is that Crouchy?
No, it's Steve Merchant.
I mean, I love Pringles.
Yeah.
And I'm pleased to see Crouchy's associated. But I was disappointed...
Don't bother mentioning Pringles, thinking you'll get some free Pringles because he went on about munchies and then we not got a fucking sniff.
True. True.
What do you think of that, Karl?
But are you a fan of Crouchy? You must be.
They're all much of a muchness, honestly.
That's nonsense.
I didn't want to come in here and start talking about football. I'll watch it.

What do you mean I didn't want to come in here. What a thing to say. Imagine Gary Lineker going, "Hello. Welcome to the BBC. I didn't want to be here today. Talk about football. Fed up. I've got better things to do."

No, but it's something you talk about. I mean, it's ridiculous coming in here, talking about it before we've even kicked the ball. Who knows what's going to happen. If there's one thing that's good about it, it's that in it, not knowing.

Well, that's what I don't understand. I don't understand all this punditry. Why we have a three hour build up, then they talk about it half time, then they talk about it for half hour afterwards. I mean, for me it's like "It's kick off." "Who won?" "They did." "Three one." "All right, cheers. Let's get on with work."

But also, we like the whinging after. We are a... This country loves the moan. They love it. I love it. Love a good moan. I don't know how we'd be if we won. We'd go, "All right, yeah.." What was he talking about?
Yeah.
You see, back in 1966, people weren't as miserable.
No.
Okay, well, hang on. I'd like to hear this theory extrapolated.
Well, they weren't, were they? People were. The war had happened, like, not that long ago.
Right.
People getting on with it. 66. Everyone's smart. You dressed up if you went out. They weren't on as much money.
The footballers?
Footballers. It was just a game of football. Whereas now it's like all this build up going on. Just get on with it. I'm sick of it. Honestly, I'm sick and tired of hearing.
I'm with you. I do think it's ridiculous that there's a match and the program before it's like 2 hours before it, and then an hour after.
Well, that's just a shameless attempt to keep people. I mean, let's be honest. You and I have been guilty of being involved with them. We've done various little skits and sketches in the past.
But that's fun. I mean, we do that for us, not for them. I don't care whether people like it or not. I did it because it was fun. I dressed up you and a dwarf. The day doesn't get better than that.

Well, I was in a pub watching that year, and I'd forgotten that we'd done that, or at least that it was going to be shown that day. So I'm in this pub, it's rammed, obviously, and that comes on the telly, on the big screen, and suddenly that's that sketch, right? A couple of things annoy me. One, no one was paying attention. I was furious. I was thinking there's a couple of good looking birds here, at least on the fucking telly. Look at the telly. Me and on a sketch with Ricky Gervais and Warwick Davis. I'm playing Crouchy. No one not paying attention. The few that were, not amused at all, could not get. My mother, of course, remembers famously said, that's the funniest thing you've ever done, which we'd knocked up in about 20 minutes. No one in the pub seemed interested. And then a few people like, looked round, looked at me, looked at the screen, sort of shrugged, carried on going. Nothing. But also kind of it is embarrassing, that situation.

I was on a flight, internal flight in America. And on the internal flights you don't get individual screens, they give you individual players. But there's also screens all down the aisle for people, right? But Ghost Town was on. Looked over someone watching Extras. And I had to make sure that at no point did I glance up at the screen like he's watching himself and make sure I flicked over whenever it came up. The office or extras.
Yeah.

If I'm on the tube and I'm flipping through the paper, sometimes there'll be an interview with you that I'm not aware is going to be in the paper and I have to flip on by because I don't want a bloke on the tube going, "Oh reading about your mate, are you?"
Ricky laughs
Yeah.
"Don't get enough of him. Do you?" Do you know what i mean?
I know.
Karl?
Have you been recognized? Do you ever get recognised much?

Yeah, now and again, but I haven't done anything of any worth have I? It's almost like recognizing a neighbour or something, because they sort of go, "Oh, it's him." And then the other one might go, "What's he do?" "I don't know." It's not like I've done something...
Right of any worth.
Of any worth yet.

None of us has done anything of any worth. It's all relative to the entertainment industry. Whatever you think of The Office, I'm very proud of it. But I haven't secured a bunker in enemy territory. I haven't given a kidney away. Do you know what I mean? It's all relative. It's just, did you entertain anyone? Did you bring a smile to someone's face? Was it a laugh? I think you're forgetting all those emails I pass on to you for those people that have had traumas in their lives. The earthquake victim. There's people that have lost relatives or had terrible life threatening diseases and they say the podcast got them through. Doesn't that warm the cockles of your heart?
Well, normally it's gone straight to you hasn't it and you just forward me on. So it's almost like spam to me.
Steve laughs
It doesn't feel as special because it's like, here you go. Look at this. You know?
Unbelievable.
New segment music
I've got the new iPad. I've had it for a few months, actually. It got sent to me by the inventor. That's who you're dealing with there, Steve.
Bloody hell.
You've got it, aren't you?
Still getting free shit.
My favourite app on this is that you just type in what you want it to say and it says it.
App speaks in a male voice, "Karl has got a head like a fucking orange. The cunt."
It's good that.
It's almost certainly what it was designed for.
I haven't seen that on the advert.
Ricky laughs
App speaks in a female voice, "Karl has got a head like a fucking orange. The cunt." Ricky laughs.
She sounds like a radio four news announcer.
So what is that for?
For doing that.
App speaks in a female voice, "Karl has got a head like a fucking orange. The cunt."
Yeah.
App speaks in a female voice, "Did I mention his round head?"
Good, right. And so...
I think I first became really excited by the World cup, that famous year when Maradona did the handball. Do you remember? What was that, 1986?
Yeah.
Oh, that was so exciting, because obviously he'd been so brilliant in that tournament. And then he did cheat, as we all know.
Yeah.
What do you make of that? Do you remember that moment, Karl? That was very formative for me.
I know what I made of it.
App speaks in a female voice, "The cunt." Ricky and Steve laugh.
I don't know. Isn't cheating part of all games now?
Hang on, here we go. This is controversial.
Go on...
There's a lot of young people who look up to Karl as a role model.
Yeah.
Yeah, but it's the world we live in now, isn't it? It's get what you can, how you can.
But what's your feeling? Are you the sort of person. I mean, have you ever cheated in a game? Are you that sort of person?
I just think me dad does it a lot.
What, in board games and that?
Yeah. Just cards. Monopoly.
How does he cheat a Monopoly?
Just nicks a lot of the money.
Oh, just straightforward nicks the money. I hadn't thought of that. I love that.
But how do you not notice he's doing it? If he does it all the time.
I'm busy looking at what properties I've invested in and stuff.
Sure.
And the money's just there isn't it?
I don't see the point of cheating in Monopoly.
No, I don't.

I say that to him. I say, you're kidding yourself. You're kidding yourself. But to him, he's broke the system hasn't he. He's got round the rules. What do you mean? I can only have that much. Who says I can? Bosch. Get some more money, buy some more hotels. And in a way, that's life in it. All people with loads of money. Now you kind of go, have they made that honestly? You know, I pass big houses in London and I think, gangsters. Gotta be gangsters to have a house like that. There's no way a normal job, someone who's. Because I know. I'm trying to make money, and I know how hard it is to make money, because the more money you make, the more hands are out there taking little bits. So how the HELL has this man bought this house? He's gotta be a crook.
So do you yourself cheat? Would you consider yourself a cheater?
Are you honourable?
In games?
Well, just generally. Do you cheat on anything?

No. Do you know what? The other week, I'd had a cup of tea and some fish and chips at this pub, and they only took for one. And I went back the next day and said, oh, you didn't charge me for me fish and chips.
What a fucking moron.
I paid. No, I didn't tell her about the tea, though.
Steve bursts into laughter
Got a free tea.
The free tea.
Yeah.
I just thought, well, it's pretty good that I've gone back to pay for that. How much is a tea bag? The water's free.
Yeah.

I'll have that for free. So again, that's just me. It's like the Mars bar and the paper round. It's me going, well, I've been good. The fish would have cost money. Potatoes are pretty cheap, but I'll pay for it. But for my goodness, as a little gift, have a free cup of tea.
But who's giving you the right to make that decision?

That's me that. That's me. I'm deciding there. I'm in charge. I didn't have to go in there, didn't have to go back and pay, but I went back and paid. Tell you what Karl, treat yourself. How's that? Have the cup of tea. All right, I will do. There's the fish and chips.
Someone plays automated voice saying "Absolute bollocks"
If she was good at her job, she'd have remembered. I thought she would have done. In a way it annoyed me that she didn't go, oh, yeah. So you did. Well done. Thank you very much for coming back.
Right.
She just was like, did you?
Not enough gratitude. I know what you mean.
She looked at me like, we didn't even know.
Yeah.
I was worrying about a staff member.
Getting fired or something.
Getting done or having to pay for it.
I know where you're coming at there.

One of my first disappointments with football, I was ten years old, okay. And one of the teachers was in charge of the football team, my junior school, and I went down to Tutty's. It was a shop in reading, my mum, so it's. White socks, black shorts, white shirt. Went to. Knocked on his door. I said, I've got my kit. He went with the trials yesterday. You've missed it. That was it for a year, right? Next year, where the trials? Where the trials? Got to the trials, okay, he was going, everyone, I want to give 100%. Really try hard. Really try hard. He's watching people play, right? I made sure that every time I ran by him, I was out of breath. Every time. Ran by him, he sort of looked at me, I think. Yeah. Came to it. He said, the team is this. I'm left out, right? He went past me and he went, you've clearly got asthma.
Steve laughs
So you didn't make that team either.
Yeah, and I didn't. And I vowed that day, never try hard at anything.
Yeah, well, you've certainly kept that up.
Yeah. What's your thoughts on that, Karl?
Did you play sport at school?

A little bit, but it was never taken seriously at school anyway. I think the PE teacher was a geography teacher as well. So it's like, what does he know? It was all that, basically. He put some tracksuit pants on that were always too tight for him. Could see everything.
Why were you looking at...? Did you...?
Because you couldn't help it. It was in the days when clothing was tight as it is, and then it was like, lycra trackie bottoms.
Oh right.
And everyone used to say, look at the state of that.
Thought he was stealing sausages from Londis?

It was ridiculous. Ridiculous. So he didn't know what he was doing anyway. If anything it was dangerous because he didn't know what was the capability of a ten year old kid's body. He put you through loads of stuff.
Right.
He didn't like me anyway because I wasn't that good. If you're not that good, teachers don't like you.
I thought you'd be pretty good.
I wasn't interested. That's the thing. I did relay and I got done for swearing. Got whacked on the arse with a baton.
Hold on, why were you swearing in relay? When did that come into it? When do you need to swear in relay? You're running around. How did they know you were swearing?

Because the lads wouldn't slow down, so I couldn't pass it on. So I sort of said, fucking slow down and he heard me and then went mental at me. But, yeah, so it was never. I mean, Darren Campbell, the athlete, I've told you that I was involved in his training.
No. Don't know about this.
Yeah. Darren Campbell. I think he won a gold medal.
Didn't he used to push you around in a bath or sommat?
It's not Last of the Summer Wine.
Ricky bursts in to laughter.
It was in my go kart. It was a motorised go kart. And you had to pick it up at the back, run with it at speed and then drop the wheels down and the engine kicked in.
But hold on, though. That means you always needed two people to get you going on the go kart?
No one. He did it.
Well, where were you?
Sat in it.
Well, then you did need two then to get it going.
What are you on about?
I was sat in it.
Yeah.
He picks it up.
Um.
Runs with it.
Yeah.
Drops it down.
Karl makes thud noise.
Wheels start. Engine starts. Off I go.
But what would you have done without him?
Well, I couldn't have done it.
So you do need two people, then, for this motor?
One person. I'm sat in it.
Yeah, but counting you, it's two people needed.
Yeah.
Fuck me.
Jesus Christ.
What's so bad about that?
Well, how can you have a play with yourself, then?
Steve chuckles.
In your go Kart.
Ricky laughs.
Sorry, This was part of his official Olympic training.
No, but I just feel like that was part of his early training, which is the important bit in any job, or.
No, we should explain. People don't know. He was the bloke who used to push the bobsleigh in the Winter Olympics, wasn't he, for the England team?
No, he was a runner.
Well, how is that part of his training, then, pushing a fucking go kart?
What was he doing?
Because he's running.
But he's running about a yard!
No, no, sometimes more than that. Quite a lot. And it's just. God, what do you. It's Darren Campbell pushing me go kart.
Yeah but you seem to
You seem to be taking half the credit for his gold medal. All you've done is sat on your arse, you lazy twat.

I just kind of think he was- he was at the age where it's important, he could have made a decision not to go into it at that point. And I think he was never keen to get in the go cart. He was always keen to push it, and I used to let him. Now, if I said, no, I don't want you pushing me go cart, who knows? I'm just saying, I was there at the start.
Doing nothing, providing nothing.
Sitting on your arse.
Sitting around, letting someone else do it.
